newsitem.title: USA: Trump hopes to trump with poker tourney.
newsitem.headline: Trump hopes to trump with poker tourney.

text.p: Donald Trump, facing growing competition from Connecticut and a revamped Tropicana casino in Atlantic City, sought help from some high rollers: the world's top poker players.
The 24-day United States Poker Championships, the first major tournament on the East Coast, was winding up Friday night at Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc.'s Taj Mahal Casino.
In its first year, the Trump tournament has far outstripped the World Poker Finals, now entering its fifth year at Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard, Conn.

Measured by total stakes, the Poker Championships has topped $4 million in its first year. That's a tie with the Four Queens Classic in Las Vegas and second only to the 27-year-old World Series of Poker, the first and best known tournament that had $11 million in play last spring.

Tournament poker differs from the brand played around the kitchen table. Because it is designed to produce a single winner, players cannot quit while they're ahead. They must keep playing until one contestant holds all the chips.
No longer winner-take-all, tournaments now give some award to every player who is still in contention when the field has been reduced to a single table.
But the stars are the champions. And the Taj Mahal this week was full of them.
Many were Europeans, like Surindar Sunar of Wolverhampton, England, who found Atlantic City easier to reach than Las Vegas.
"Poker is really exploding in Europe," said Donnacher O'Dea of Dublin, a poker professional.
The 100 players who paid the $7,500 entry fee are contesting for 18 playing places, with $500,000 guaranteed to the final player. The Taj Mahal added $100,000 to create a total purse of $850,000.
Two recent World Series winners, Johnny Chan and Huck Seed, were among the 55 entrants to fall victim to the intense competition in the first day.

Until this year, the Taj had dominated the Atlantic City poker scene with more tables in play than the other card rooms combined. Then the Tropicana casino opened a card room of equal size and hired away several key Taj Mahal managers.
In addition to local competitors, Trump's Atlantic City casinos face competition from two Indian-run casinos in Connecticut.
The Taj's card room manager, Tom Gitto, said, "We did not expect to make money the first year, but we have been pleasantly surprised."
He said the contestants have spurred non-tournment play for higher stakes. The casino gets its poker revenues by taking a percentage of the bets.
